720955f.title: Manhattan: Lexington Avenue - 37th Street (East)
720955f.text:
Lexington Avenue, at the N. E. corner of East 37th Street (right).
showing the newly constructed Hotel White at that locatien.
About 1925.
Underwood and Enderwood
No reproductione.

720958f-a.title: Manhattan: Lexington Avenue - 37th Street
720958f-a.text:
Lexington Avenue, west side, south frorm East 38th
to 37th Streets. The far corner of this block front was
demolished in 1940 and replaced by the Lindley Houuse, an
apartment structure. Otherwise these remsin as shown
with the exception of the iron railings.
April 13, 1924
Standard Photographic Service
Gift of Borough President of Wanhnttan
CREDIT LINE IMPERATOVE

712411f-a.title: Manhattan: 37th Street (East) - Lexington Avenue
712411f-a.text:
152-162 Eaat 37th Street, on the south side, west of Lexington
Avenue; a new apartment building is nearing completion on the site
of three old houses, Nos. 156-l60 East 37th Street.
1924.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

720956f-a.title: Manhattan: Lexington Avenue - 37th Street (East)
720956f-a.text:
Lexington Avenue (right), at the N.W. corner
of East 37th Street, showing a group of houses that
are to be replaced by a modern apartment building.
Same being the 3-structures (Note 296 to 300) forming
the corner plot of 60x90, according to a report listed
in the New York Times of March 9, 1.38. This new struc-
ture will be 14-stories high and contain 94 suites. This
is under construction in March, 1940 and will be known as
Lindley House.
March, 1938
George D. Chinn
NO REPRODUCTIONS

720957f-a.title: Manhattan: Lexington Avenue - 37th Street (East)
720957f-a.text:
Lexington Avenue, north from East 37th Street,
showing prominently the weiterly frontage. The Lindley
House was erected (in 1940) t the corner site on the
left.
April 13, 1924
Standard Photographic Service
Gift of Borough President of Manhattan
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE

712412f-a.title: Manhattan: 37th Street - Lexington Avenue
712412f-a.text:
37th Street, north side, from Lexington Avenue to and including
Park. Nos. 117 and 119 have just been sold by Mrs. 2. M. Peters
after having been in the family for fifty-four years. No. 119
is the 2-story garage.
October 12, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
According to the New York Times of March 29, 1938 the structures
at the right, comprising a portion of a 60E90 plot at the N.W. corner
of Lexington Ave. and East 37th Street, will be demolished and a
new 14-story apartment house ereoted there at a cost of 500,000.

712413f-a.text:
